name: pentanols production, hydroformylation of butene | 3-methyl-1-butanol | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/9962/documentation

This data represents the multioutput-process "hydroformulation of butene."  This process delivers the co-products 1-pentanol, 2-methyl-1-butanol and 3-methyl-1-butanol based off of 1 kg of butene.  The raw materials are modelled with stoichiometric calculations.  The energy consumption and auxilliaries are modelled with data from a similar process.  The emissions are estimated. Infrastructure is included with a default value. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From the reception of butene at the factory gate.

This activity includes the hydroformylation by a carbon monoxide and hydrogen stream and the subsequent hydrogenation resulting in the production of the three isomers 1-pentanol, 2-methyl-1-butanol and 3-methyl-1-butanol.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Hydroformylation of butenes (1-butene, 2-butene, and isobutene, all with the gross formula C4H8)  with a CO (50% mass of butenes) and H (7% mass of butenes) gas stream, yields the amyl alcohols (C5H12O).;The C4-olefins are reacted with a carbon monoxide – hydrogen mixture under the catalytic action of cobalt- or rhodium- containing compounds to yield C5-aldehydes. Hydrogenation of the latter gives the corresponding C5-alcohols. ;a) Oxo reactor (100 – 200 °C, 10 – 45 MPa); b) Separator; c) Catalyst removal (decobalting); d) Hydrogenation unit (50 – 250 °C, 0.3 – 24 MPa); e) Catalyst recovery;Raffinate I from various cracking processes (after the separation of 1,3-butadiene) is used as raw material and contains ca. 44 – 49 vol % isobutene, 24 – 28 vol % 1-butene, 19 – 21 vol % 2-butene, and 8 – 11 vol % C4-hydrocarbons. Further processing of this C4-raffinate converts isobutene by reaction with methanol to methyl tert-butyl ether. The remaining C4-olefin mixture (raffinate II) is the most important raw material in the industrial production of 1-pentanol and 2-methyl-1-butanol.;Cobalt-catalyzed hydroformylation of n-butenes and subsequent hydrogenation yield a mixture containing ca. 70 % 1-pentanol and 30 % 2-methyl-1-butanol. If rhodium – triphenylphosphane is used as catalyst, a mixture containing up to 90 % 1-pentanol and 10 % 2-methyl-1-butanol is obtained.;2-Butene can be converted to mixtures of C5-aldehydes of varying composition, depending on the rhodium-containing catalyst system and reaction conditions. Thus, a ratio of 1.13:1 of 1-pentanal to 2-methylbutanal is obtained with a rhodium – phosphite catalyst at 130 °C; a ratio of 0.2:1 is obtained by hydroformylation with a rhodium – tricyclohexylphosphane catalyst at 110 °C. The dependence of the n:i ratio on catalyst species and temperature during conversion of 1-butene and 2-butene with a rhodium –triarylphosphane catalyst system is given in.;;References:;Lappe, P., Hoffmann, T.: Pentanols. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/articles

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
3-methyl-1-butanol is a colourless liquid of characteristic odor. It is only sparingly miscible with water at 20 °C. However, it is almost completely miscible with most organic solvents.

3-Methyl-1-butanol is used mainly as a solvent and extracting agent in several practical applications. An important use is in the production of di(3-methylbutyl) ether; the latter is a component of a catalyst system used for the industrial production of polypropylene. Other uses of 3-methyl-1-butanol in catalysis are discussed in.
3-Methyl-1-butanol is used in the production of herbicides based on 1,2,4-triazolecarboxamides, N-methyl- 4-pyridone derivatives, and substituted phenylhydrazones. It is also employed for the synthesis of fragrances and flavors: 3-methyl-1-butanol reacts e.g., with ethylidenenorbornene to give the corresponding norbornyl ether, with bicyclopentadiene to yield tricyclo[5.2.1.02.6]dec-3-en-8(9)-yl-3-methylbutyl ether, and with vanillin alcohol to give the corresponding vanillin ether derivative.
3-Methyl-1-butanol is also used for the production of various additives, corrosion inhibitors, and azo dyes. It is a component of surfactants.

flow.name: 3-methyl-1-butanol
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
Estimation.   Air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated to 0.2% of the butene and the carbon monoxide input and 5% of the hydrogen input. The remaining CO is oxidated to CO2

The carbon contained in the removed butene during waste water treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air.

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: Estimation.  Estimated with data from the production of isobutanol from the hydroformylation of propylene.  This process is considered to be similar to the hydroformylation of butene.

exchanges.description:
Estimation.   Air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated to 0.2% of the butene and the carbon monoxide input and 1% of the hydrogen input. The remaining CO is oxidated to CO2

The carbon contained in the removed butene during waste water treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air.

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

flow.name: Hydrogen
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
DOC assumed equal to TOC.
It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

Water emissions are assumed to be emitted into rivers.

flow.name: DOC, Dissolved Organic Carbon
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The remaining amount of unreacted butene (4.8 % of the input) was assumed to leave the production process with the waste water. Further it was assumed that this waste water is treated in a internal waste water plant. The removal efficiency for butene was assumed with 90%. The carbon contained in the
removed butene was accounted as CO2 emissions to air.
 It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

The emissions into water are assumed to be emitted into rivers.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

Water emissions are assumed to be emitted into rivers.

exchanges.description: Air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated to 0.2% of the butene and the carbon monoxide input and 5% of the hydrogen input. 4.8% of the carbon monoxide is oxidised to CO2. 4.8% of the butene is in treated waste water, with 90% efficiency, i.e. 90% of the 4.8% is oxidised to CO2.
